title: Basic Sentence Structure
description: Learn the fundamental word order in te reo Māori sentences.

content.title: Word Order in Te Reo Māori

elements.content:
## Word Order Differences

In te reo Māori, [[ref|sentences|rerenga]] typically follow a different pattern than English.

The basic word order is:
* **[[ref|Verb-Subject-Object|sentence-structure]]** (VSO) in te reo Māori
* Compared to English which uses Subject-Verb-Object (SVO)

> Understanding this fundamental difference is key to forming correct sentences.

A te reo Māori [[ref|sentence|rerenga]] has three main components:

1. The [[ref|predicate|kianga]] - what is being said
2. The [[ref|subject|tuingoa]] - who or what we're talking about
3. Comments - additional information

These form the building blocks of every sentence you'll create.

These components form a complete thought and can be analysed at different levels:

| Level | Description | Te Reo Term |
|-------|-------------|-------------|
| [[ref|Sentence|rerenga]] | Complete thought | Rerenga |
| [[ref|Clause|kianga]] | Contains a subject and predicate | Kianga |
| [[ref|Phrase|kianga]] | Group of related words | Kianga |
| [[ref|Word|tumu]] | Single unit of language | Tumu |

Understanding these levels helps break down complex sentences.

elements.sentence: Kei te kai a Mere i te āporo.

sentence.text: Kei te kai a Mere i te āporo.
sentence.explanation: This is a complete verbal sentence (reremahi) in the present continuous tense.

clause.explanation: This is the main clause (aho motuhake) stating who is doing the action.
This is the object clause showing what is being acted upon.

phrase.explanation: This is a verb phrase (kīanga tūmahi) with the present continuous marker and verb.
This is a noun phrase (kīanga tūingoa) with the personal article 'a' and a proper noun.
This is a prepositional phrase (kīanga pūhono) showing the direct object with the marker 'i'.

word.explanation: Present tense marker (pūmahi) forming part of 'kei te'.
Part of the verbal particle 'kei te' indicating present continuous tense.
Personal article (pūmoko) used before proper nouns.
Object marker (pūhono) used with transitive verbs to indicate direct object.

elements.sentence: Kei te mahi a Hemi i te whare nui.
elements.translation: Hemi is working on the big house.

sentence.text: Kei te mahi a Hemi i te whare nui.
sentence.explanation: This is a complete verbal sentence in the present continuous tense.
sentence.translation: Hemi is working on the big house.

clause.explanation: This is the main clause stating who is doing the action.
This is the object clause showing what is being worked on.

phrase.explanation: This is a verb phrase with the present continuous marker and the verb "mahi" (to work).
This is a noun phrase with the personal article 'a' and a proper noun.
This is a prepositional phrase with both a preposed periphery "i" and a postposed periphery "nui" (big) modifying the noun.

word.explanation: Present tense marker forming part of 'kei te'.
Part of the verbal particle 'kei te' indicating present continuous tense.
Transitive verb meaning 'to work' or 'to do'.
Personal article used before proper nouns.
Object marker used with transitive verbs to indicate direct object.

elements.content:
## Phrase Components

In te reo Māori, phrases are structured with these components:

1. **Preposed periphery** - Elements that come before the nucleus (such as articles, prepositions)
2. **Nucleus** - The central, required part of the phrase (typically a noun or verb)
3. **Postposed periphery** - Elements that come after the nucleus (such as modifiers or adjectives)

The example sentences in this lesson show these components highlighted for each phrase.

> This **phrase structure** is important to understand as you build more complex sentences.

title: Basic Sentence Structure in Te Reo Māori
description: Learn about the fundamental VSO word order and how it differs from English.

content.title: Word Order in Te Reo Māori

elements.content: Te reo Māori sentences typically follow a different pattern than English. The basic word order is Verb-Subject-Object (VSO), compared to English which uses Subject-Verb-Object (SVO).

elements.sentence: Kei te kai a Mere i te āporo.

sentence.text: Kei te kai a Mere i te āporo.
sentence.explanation: This is a complete verbal sentence following the VSO pattern: verb phrase (kei te kai) + subject (a Mere) + object (i te āporo).

clause.explanation: This is the main clause stating who is performing the action.
This is the object clause showing what is being eaten.

phrase.explanation: This is a verb phrase with the present continuous marker and verb.
This is a noun phrase with the personal article and name.
This is a prepositional phrase with the direct object marker, article, and noun.

word.explanation: Personal article used before proper nouns.
Direct object marker indicating what is receiving the action.

content.title: The Components of a Basic Sentence

elements.content: Every basic verbal sentence in te reo Māori has these components: 1) Verb phrase (what's happening), 2) Subject (who/what is doing it), and 3) Object (who/what is affected by the action).

elements.sentence: Kei te kōrero a Hemi ki a Wiremu.

sentence.text: Kei te kōrero a Hemi ki a Wiremu.
sentence.explanation: This follows the pattern: verb phrase + subject + indirect object.

clause.explanation: The main clause stating who is speaking.
The directional clause showing who James is talking to.

phrase.explanation: Verb phrase with present continuous marker.

elements.content: Can you identify the verb, subject, and object in these sentences?

elements.sentence: Kei te pānui a Rangi i te pukapuka.

sentence.text: Kei te pānui a Rangi i te pukapuka.
sentence.explanation: This follows the VSO pattern: verb (kei te pānui) + subject (a Rangi) + object (i te pukapuka).

clause.explanation: Main clause stating who is reading.
Object clause stating what is being read.

phrase.explanation: Noun phrase - who is doing it.
Prepositional phrase - what is being affected.

title: Simple Sentences Without Verbs
description: Learn about he and ko sentences in te reo Māori - two important non-verbal sentence types.

elements.content: Unlike English, te reo Māori can form complete sentences without using verbs. These non-verbal sentences are used to express identity, classification, and characteristics without needing a word for "is" or "are".

content.title: Ko Sentences - Identifying Who or What Something Is

elements.content: Ko sentences are used to express the identity of someone or something. They typically answer the question "Who is this?" or "What is this?"

content.title: He Sentences - Classifying What Something Is

elements.content: He sentences are used to express the nature or characteristics of something. They describe what category or class something belongs to.
Ko sentences identify something specific (This is X). He sentences classify something (This is a X) or describe its qualities (This is X-like).

title: Non-Verbal Sentence Types
description: Explore the different types of non-verbal sentences in te reo Māori and their uses.

elements.content: Unlike English, te reo Māori can form complete sentences without using verbs. These non-verbal sentences are used to express identity, classification, and characteristics without needing a word for "is" or "are".

content.title: Ko Sentences - Identifying Who or What Something Is

elements.content: Ko sentences are used to express the identity of someone or something. They typically answer the question "Who is this?" or "What is this?"

Ko sentences identify something specific (This is X). He sentences classify something (This is a X) or describe its qualities (This is X-like).

title: Verbal Particles
description: Learn about the particles that indicate tense, aspect, and mood in te reo Māori.

elements.content: Verbal particles (pūmahi) are small words that come before verbs in te reo Māori to indicate when an action occurs (tense), how it unfolds over time (aspect), and the speaker's attitude toward the action (mood).
The verbal particle kei te indicates an action that is happening right now (present continuous):
The verbal particle i indicates an action that happened in the past (simple past tense):

elements.sentence: I haere mātou ki te tāone.

elements.content: The verbal particle ka can indicate future actions, new actions in a narrative, or habitual actions:

elements.sentence: Ka haere au ki te kura āpōpō.
elements.translation: I will go to school tomorrow.

elements.content: The verbal particle kua indicates a completed action with present relevance (perfect aspect):
The verbal particles e...ana surround a verb to indicate an ongoing action (continuous aspect):

elements.sentence: E mahi ana ia i āna mahi kāinga.

title: Word Classes in Te Reo Māori
description: Learn about the main types of words and their functions in te reo Māori sentences.

elements.content: In te reo Māori, words are categorized into different classes based on their function in a sentence. Understanding these word classes is fundamental to constructing grammatically correct sentences.
Tūmahi are words that describe actions, states of being, or occurrences. In te reo Māori, verbs can be classified into several important categories:
Intransitive verbs (like "sleep"), transitive verbs (like "eat something"), stative verbs (like "be happy"), and neuter verbs (like "be broken").
Tūingoa are words that name people, places, things, or ideas. Te reo Māori has concrete nouns (physical objects), abstract nouns (concepts), and proper nouns (names).
Tūkapi are words that replace nouns in a sentence. Te reo Māori has a complex pronoun system that tells you not just "who" but also how many people and whether the listener is included.

elements.sentence: au/ahau = I, koe = you, ia = he/she
tātou = we all (including you), mātou = we all (excluding you)

elements.content: Tūpātai are words used to ask questions in te reo Māori.

elements.sentence: aha = what, wai = who, hea = where

title: Commands and Negation
description: Learn how to give commands and make negative statements in te reo Māori.

elements.content: Commands or imperative sentences tell someone to do something. In te reo Māori, there are several ways to form commands.
The simplest form of a command uses just the verb:
Commands can also be formed with the particle e:
Commands can be given in the passive voice, especially for transitive verbs:
To make a verbal sentence negative, we generally use the negative word kāore:

elements.sentence: Kei te haere a Mere. → Kāore a Mere i te haere.
elements.translation: Mary is going. → Mary is not going.

elements.sentence: I kai ia. → Kāore ia i kai.
elements.translation: She ate. → She did not eat.

elements.content: To negate ko sentences, we use the negative word ehara:

elements.sentence: Ko Hera ahau. → Ehara au i a Hera.
elements.translation: I am Hera. → I am not Hera.

elements.content: To negate he sentences, we use either ehara or kāore depending on the context:

elements.sentence: He kaiako ia. → Ehara ia i te kaiako.
elements.translation: She is a teacher. → She is not a teacher.

title: Questions in Te Reo Māori
description: Learn how to ask different types of questions in te reo Māori.

elements.content: Asking questions is an essential part of communication. In te reo Māori, there are several ways to form questions depending on what information you're seeking.
To ask a question that can be answered with "yes" or "no," simply use the same structure as a statement but with a rising intonation at the end:

elements.sentence: Kei te haere koe ki te kura?
I kai koe i te paraoa?

elements.content: To ask about things, use the question word aha (what):
To ask about people, use the question word wai (who):
To ask about locations, use the question word hea (where):
There are several other question words in te reo Māori:
āhea (when - future), nōnāhea (when - past), pēhea (how), hia (how many - things), tokohia (how many - people)

title: Phrases in Te Reo Māori
description: Learn about different types of phrases and their functions in sentences.

elements.content: Phrases are groups of related words that function as a unit within a sentence. Understanding phrases is key to forming more complex sentences.
Verb phrases contain a verb and any associated particles. They typically form the predicate of a sentence:

elements.sentence: Kei te kai, ka haere, i moe

elements.content: Noun phrases contain a noun and any associated articles, modifiers, or possessives:

elements.sentence: te whare nui, aku pukapuka, a Hemi
elements.translation: the big house, my books, James

elements.content: Prepositional phrases begin with a preposition and typically indicate location, direction, or relationship:

elements.sentence: ki te kura, i te whare, mō te tamaiti
elements.translation: to school, in the house, for the child

elements.content: Phrases can be joined together using me (and) or hoki (also):

elements.translation: the meat, and also the kumara

elements.content: The typical order of phrases in a sentence is: Predicate phrase (verb phrase) + Subject phrase (noun phrase) + Other phrases (comments).

title: Advanced Verb Forms
description: Learn about experience verbs, neuter verbs, and passive constructions.

elements.content: Experience verbs describe perceptions, emotions, or mental states. They work differently from standard action verbs:

elements.sentence: Kei te pīrangi au ki te kai.
Kei te mōhio ia ki te kōrero Māori.
elements.translation: She knows how to speak Māori.

elements.content: Neuter verbs (tūmahi oti) describe states resulting from completed actions. They often translate to "be broken," "be finished," etc.:
With neuter verbs, you can optionally indicate who or what caused the state:

elements.sentence: Kua pakaru te wini i a Hemi.
elements.translation: The window is broken because of James.

elements.content: The passive voice shifts focus from the doer to the receiver of an action. In te reo Māori, this involves adding a special suffix to the verb:

elements.sentence: Kei te kai a Mere i te āporo. → Kei te kainga te āporo e Mere.
elements.translation: Mary is eating the apple. → The apple is being eaten by Mary.

elements.content: Different verbs take different passive suffixes, such as -tia, -hia, -ngia, -a, and others:
Another way to form passive-like sentences is using the construction "he mea..." (it is a thing...):

elements.sentence: He mea tuhi tēnei reta e Hemi.
elements.translation: This letter was written by James.

title: A/O Categories of Possession
description: Learn about the two categories of possession in te reo Māori and when to use each.

elements.content: Te reo Māori divides possession into two categories, known as the A category and the O category. This affects which possessive forms to use (taku/tōku, aku/ōku, etc.).
The O category generally includes things that:

* Are your superiors, elders, or ancestors
* Shelter, protect, or transport you
* Are parts of your body or mind
* Are your home, land, or heritage

elements.translation: O category - the house shelters you

elements.content: The A category generally includes things that:

* Are your subordinates or younger relations
* Are controlled by you
* Are food or drink
* Are created, acquired, or owned by you

elements.translation: A category - work is controlled/done by you
A category - children are younger relations

elements.content: Some items can change category depending on the relationship or context. It's not about the object itself but the relationship between possessor and possessed.

title: Complex Sentences
description: Learn how to form more complex sentence structures with multiple clauses.

elements.content: Complex sentences contain multiple clauses - one main clause and one or more subordinate clauses that add additional information.
These clauses indicate when an action takes place:

elements.sentence: Ka haere au ki te kāinga i te mutunga o te mahi.
elements.translation: I will go home at the end of work.

elements.content: These clauses indicate why an action is performed:

elements.sentence: I haere ia ki te toa ki te hoko kai.
elements.translation: She went to the store to buy food.

elements.content: These clauses express conditions under which something happens:

elements.sentence: Mehemea ka ua, ka noho tātou ki roto.
elements.translation: If it rains, we will stay inside.

elements.content: These clauses provide additional information about a noun:

elements.sentence: Kei te pānui au i te pukapuka i homai e taku hoa ki ahau.
elements.translation: I am reading the book that my friend gave to me.

elements.content: These clauses make comparisons:

elements.sentence: He pai ake tēnei pukapuka i tērā.
elements.translation: This book is better than that one.

title: Pronunciation
description: Learn how to pronounce Māori words.

elements.content:
There are a wide variety of resources available to support you in learning how to pronounce te reo Māori. Rather than reproduce those here, this section will give a brief overview and link to other resources online to support your pronunciation.

Some good ways to practice your pronunciation include:
* Te Wānanga o Aotearoa's [Māori Alphabet Tool](https://purarangi.twoa.ac.nz/).
* Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa's [Video Tutorials](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jTP-nRudTy8).
* Looking up words on [Te Aka Māori Dictionary](https://maoridictionary.co.nz/word/3003) and using the audio pronunciation feature (to the right of the word) to listen to how words and pick up the individual sounds.
* Using an app such as [Rongo](https://rongo.app/) to practice and test your pronunciation.

Te reo Māori has five vowels, but these can be pronounced and combined in different ways to make a much larger number of total vowel sounds. Vowels can be long or short, with the long version of a vowel sound typically indicated by a macron* (a straight bar placed above the letter).

The vowels are a, ā, e, ē, i, ī, o, ō, u and ū.

They're pronounced like the following sounds in English:

| Vowel | Short Sound | Long Sound |
|-------|-------------|-------------|
| a/ā | **a**gree | c**a**r |
| e/ē | **e**xam | **ai**r |
| i/ī | **e**at | s**ee** |
| o/ō | **aw**ful | st**or**e |
| u/ū | tw**o** | s**oo**n |

The macron is called tohutō or pōtae (hat) in te reo Māori.

*Some iwi and speakers prefer to use a double vowel instead of a macron (e.g. turning kōrero into koorero).

Some vowels, when placed next to other vowels, require us to blend the two sounds together into a single syllable, while other vowels combinations require us to pronounce both vowels independently.

We blend the vowel into a single syllable when:
* a is followed by any other vowel ([tae](https://maoridictionary.co.nz/word/7020), [tai](https://maoridictionary.co.nz/word/7091), [hao](https://maoridictionary.co.nz/word/848), [hau](https://maoridictionary.co.nz/word/924)).
* e is followed by i or u ([kei](https://maoridictionary.co.nz/word/2514), [heu](https://maoridictionary.co.nz/word/1122)).
* o is followed by e, i or u ([koe](https://maoridictionary.co.nz/word/2761), [koi](https://maoridictionary.co.nz/word/2818), [hou](https://maoridictionary.co.nz/word/1464)).

Listen to the difference at the links above between hau/hou/hao, between koe/koi, as well as between tae and kai as these vowel blends can often be mixed up.

Additionally, some long vowels are blended with a short vowel, such as:
* ā followed by any other vowel ([pāera](https://maoridictionary.co.nz/word/4882), [kāinga](https://maoridictionary.co.nz/word/1971), [māori](https://maoridictionary.co.nz/word/3646), [māu](https://maoridictionary.co.nz/word/3931)).
* ō followed by i or u ([ōi](https://maoridictionary.co.nz/word/4717), [tōu](https://maoridictionary.co.nz/word/8547)).
* ē followed by i ([tēina](https://maoridictionary.co.nz/word/7891)).

With other vowel combinations, we pronounce both vowels as separate syllables. In the common greeting `kia ora`, `kia` has both of its vowels pronounced but the **a** of `ki**a**` and the **o** of `**o**ra` are often blended together when speaking faster. You'll often hear this with vowels at the end of a word and start of the next word.
A blend of two vowels is called a dipthong or [oro tōpū](https://paekupu.co.nz/word/oro-topu)

Te reo Māori has ten consonants: h, k, m n, p, r, t, w, wh, ng

Although vowels can appear in a word alone, consonants are always combined with a vowel to make a syllable and no word in te reo Māori ends in a consonant.

Many of the consonants in te reo Māori are used very similarly to how they're used in English, so at this early stage of your reo journey, we'll focus on just covering the sounds that are important to focus on.

* w is usually pronounced like an f, although there are dialectual variations on this.
* ng is pronounced like the **ng** in si**ng**er, although Ngāi Tahu (Kāi Tahu) speakers use a k sound .
* r is pronounced as a rolled r, similar to an English d sound, but softer. A good comparison is the **dd** sound in shu**dd**er or the **tt** in how Kiwi pronounce bu**tt**er. Thes best way to practice this is to listen to it being pronounced and imitating this in words such as [kiriata](https://maoridictionary.co.nz/word/2681).
* t is pronounced differently depending on the vowel that follows it. When followed by an a/e/u it is pronounced softer, closer to an English d sound. When followed by an i/u it is sharper like an English t sound. Compare [titiro](https://maoridictionary.co.nz/word/8226) and [tēpu](https://maoridictionary.co.nz/word/7941).

The consonants wh and ng are digraphs or [orotaki pūrua](https://paekupu.co.nz/word/orokati-purua), where two letters are used to indicate a single sound.

As you continue comparing your pronunciation to practiced speakers you may find subtle differences between other English and Māori consonants. For example, p, t and k in te reo Māori are often less aspirated than in English. Basically this means that there's less of a breath out when you use the sound.

Hold a hand in front of your mouth and compare the p in `pit` and the p in `spit` -- the p in `spit` is less aspirated!

We'll come back to pronunciation later in the lessons. There are some more complicated aspects of pronunciation to focus on (in particular which parts of a word or phrases should be emphasised to improve the rere or flow of Māori speech) but they're better addressed once we've learned a little bit more about how words and phrases are structured in te reo Māori.

title: Introductions
description: A quick overview of some simple greetings and introductions while we're getting familiar with the features of the platform.

elements.content: We'll start one of the best known Māori greetings, commonly heard in Aotearoa. Don't worry too much at this stage about what each individual word means, just take the opportunity to get familiar with reading te reo Māori and saying it aloud to yourself.

elements.note: Listen to the [recording](https://maoridictionary.co.nz/word/2608) on Te Aka and note how the two vowels in ki**a o**ra blend into one another!
Because `koutou` is a term used to address three or more people, this form of the greeting is only used if you're talking to that many people.

elements.content:
While 'kia ora' is used to say hello, its literal translation is closer to `be well`.

It's commonly considered an informal way to say hello.
These are some examples of other informal greetings and farewells:
These are some examples of more formal greetings and farewells:

elements.translation: Hello to one/two/three or more people
elements.note: In te reo Māori, you use a different term for `you` depending on how many people you are talking to, so you change between koe/kōrua/koutou depending on the situation.

elements.content: The following sentences are ways to ask someone's name, as well as how to answer that question:

Observe that in both pairs of examples, the answer takes a similar format to the question. This is a common question/answer format in te reo Māori and we'll investigate how it works as we progress through the lessons.

In te ao Māori (the Māori world), it's common for formal greetings to include details about where you come from to communicate to the listener who your ancestors are and who you might know. This gives them an opportunity to recognise and share connections that they may have with you as part of getting to know one another.

These are some of the ways that you might communicate where you come from:

elements.note:
Note that nō is a possessive term, so the question is literally asking `to where do you belong?`

Because of this detail, it can be considered improper for non-Māori to use nō to claim a connection to somewhere in Aotearoa. Not every listener is going to be find this inappropriate, but it can be more respectful to use an alternative way of describing where you come from such as some of the  options below.
The [[ref|tūkapi|tukapi]] (pronoun) ia refers to one person without reference to their gender, unlike he/she in English.
You can use nō to describe a line of connection to a place or an iwi (tribe).

elements.sentence: I whānau mai koe ki hea?
I whānau mai au ki Kirikiriroa.
I tipu ake au ki Heretaunga.

elements.content: These are just some examples of how to describe where you're from in normal conversation. A more detailed description of how to formally provide your background will be covered in a later lesson.

The following sentences can be used to ask someone how they are. Observe that similar to the earlier examples, the structure for the question and answer are very similar. In this case, the question word pēhea (how) is replaced by a word describing a feeling such as harikoa (happy) or pōuri (sad) and the word koe (you) in the sentence is replaced with au or ahau (me) for the answer.

Some other words to describe feelings include:
* pai (good)
* ora (well)
* māuiui (sick)
* hiakai (hungry)
* pukuriri (angry)

These words can replace **pōuri** or **harikoa** in the sentences above. This class of word is described more in [[ref|tūmahi ahua|tumahi-ahua]].

If you want to learn additional words to describe feelings and emotions, there's a [[vocab|feelings vocab list|feelings]] that you can use to practice.

This has provided a quick overview of how to introduce yourself in te reo Māori and introduced some of the features of the platform, including how to look at grammar references and use the Sentence Analyser.
